column1: Speech therapy is more than just clinical skills and practice. A competent speech therapist should understand the range of professional issues related to speech-language pathology which may contribute and influence their clinical practice, decision making as well as the profession. Professional issues, ethical principles and practice are introduced and illustrated by the use of case studies and discussions. Students are also introduced to applying the range of principles to ethical practice and decision making.

Speech therapy is more than just clinical skills and practice. A competent speech therapist should understand the range of professional issues related to speech-language pathology which may contribute and influence their clinical practice, decision making as well as the profession. Entry-level professional issues, advanced ethical practice and clinical decision making as well as transition to workforce issues are discussed.

This course covers basic methodology in research design in the behavioral sciences and basic statistical tools and techniques for analyzing experimental data. Knowledge and procedures of critical appraisal in the practice of evidence-based health care will be introduced. Approaches to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of clinical programmes are covered.

Assessment is a major component in the study of speech-language pathology. This course will introduce key assessment approaches including norm-referenced, criterion-referenced and dynamic tests. Students will learn about the characteristics of each type of assessment, the meaningful interpretation of test scores as well as the potential application in communication disorders in culturally and linguistically diverse populations. Students will learn major procedures in test development from item construction to data collection to evaluation. Critical concepts of psychometric properties of test evaluation will be covered.

An introduction to the anatomical and physiological aspects to the auditory, respiratory, laryngeal, and swallowing systems is provided. There will be lectures, in-class activities and laboratory sessions. Students will be exposed to anatomy and physiology software, 3D models and the 3D Anatomage Table (life-sized visualization system) to enhance learning.

This course discusses the nature, symptoms, and prevalence of stuttering disorders. Students will be provided with the basic knowledge on assessing, counselling, and treating persons with fluency disorders.

This course discusses the nature, symptoms and prevalence of voice and laryngeal disorders. Students will be provided with the basic knowledge on assessing, counselling, and treating persons with voice and laryngeal disorders.

This course gives an overview of the human's nervous system in terms of its structure and function. The primary focus is on the nervous system in the reception and expression of speech and language. Speech and language disorders resulting from cardiovascular and cerebrovascular damage due to trauma, disease and adventitious central nervous system (CNS) events will be included. Evaluation and management of the related language, speech and cognitive disorders will be covered.

The course introduces the methodologies and technologies used to promote the development of communication skills in individuals with various kinds of communication disorders including cerebral palsy and multiple disabilities. The impact of augmentative communication in social interaction, personal growth, educational & vocational opportunities, as well as other aspects of human interaction will be discussed.

The course focuses on language disorders from infancy to adolescence. The course will expose students to assessment methods and techniques encompassing the three main language domains of form, content and use with direct hands-on experience with relevant and specified standardised and non-standardised assessments. The range of treatment approaches will be covered with an emphasis on evidence-based treatment approaches and practice. Students will also be exposed to person-centred functional goals directly addressing the WHO ICF (International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health) framework. Teaching and learning enhancement techniques will include case studies, videos and role play.

This course covers children's acquisition of speech, articulatory foundations of speech, transcription of speech and classification and causes of speech sound disorders. The course will introduce students to the different types of speech sound disorders, differentiating between those involving phonology (e.g. phonological impairment) and those related to motor speech (e.g. articulation impairment). Students will also be exposed to person-centred functional goals directly addressing the WHO ICF (International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health) framework. The range of treatment approaches will be taught with an emphasis on evidence-based treatment approaches for the different types of SSD. Teaching and learning enhancement techniques will include case studies, videos and role play/simulations.

The course will cover craniofacial conditions, focusing on cleft lip and palate and craniofacial dysostosis.Students will learn how to undertaken a comprehensive perceptual assessment of cleft palate speech and velopharyngeal dysfunction using a standardized speech sampling protocol and listening protocol. Students will be exposed to treatment of cleft palate speech from early intervention to adulthood. The course will also cover instrumental assessment of cleft palate speech and velopharyngeal function. Students will also be exposed to primary and secondary (velopharyngeal) surgery in this client population and the inter-professional working paradigm within a cranofacial clinical service.

This course will cover the fundamental audiological evaluations as well as a brief introduction on more advanced approaches. Students will learn about interpretation of audiological reports, major principles of speech perception assessment and various approaches of aural (re)habilitation for populations ranging from infants to older adults.

This course aims to provide students with the fundamental knowledge of swallowing, dysphagia assessment and management. This course aims to equip students with entry-level skills to assess and manage dysphagia across all age range, in particular the adult population.

This course aims to provide students with more in-depth knowledge of swallowing, dysphagia assessment and management. This course aims to equip students with entry-level knowledge on instrumental assessment such as Fibreoptic Endoscopic Evaluation of Swallowing (FEES), Videofluoroscopic Swallow Study (VFSS) and ultrasound. It also equips students with knowledge of dysphagia in special populations such as patients with tracheostomy.

The course provides students with comprehensive knowledge of paediatric feeding and swallowing assessment and management. Content of anatomy, normal development, paediatric neurodevelopment and aero-digestive system, clinical swallowing and feeding assessment, and management will be covered. Through a combination of lectures, team-based learning, case studies, and practical exercises, students will develop a deep understanding of the complexities surrounding paediatric feeding and swallowing disorders and acquire the necessary skills to assess and manage these conditions effectively.

This course aims to prepare students to manage complex cases as an entry-level speech language pathologist. Clinical management is more complex not only when clients/patients are presented with competing communication and swallowing needs but also when their conditions interact with other challenges, such as cultural, moral, ethical, legal, and service delivery issues etc.This course adopts a team-based learning approach to allow students to reflect, discuss and problem solve to generate clinical decisions on various complex case scenarios.  Students are required to integrate the knowledge they acquired on a range of practice areas in speech language pathology while considering issues including but not limited to medical ethics, evidence-based practice, ICF model, person-centered care, interprofessional collaborative practice and culturally responsive practice.

The course is designed to provide students with basic clinical skills to prepare for clinical practice. Students will acquire basic and generic clinical skills in relation to speech language pathology through seminars, workshops, and simulated learning.

The course is designed to provide students with experiential learning for them to develop the required clinical skills in managing clients with various communication disorders. Students will be trained to manage, under supervision, paediatric and adult clients in various settings including clinics, schools, health care organizations, and hospitals.

This course introduces students to a unified approach to language as a complex structure represented in the minds of its speakers. Empirical linguistic data will be drawn across languages to enable students to understand the intimate relation between language and the human mind. On the basis of this understanding, students are led to explore the core areas of linguistics. The exploration starts with natural language sound systems and phonological components of grammar. These will be explained with basic concepts and recent theoretical advances in linguistic studies alongside new findings in language acquisition. Students will learn to apply these concepts and ideas to tackle linguistic problems.

Taking a modular approach to the language system, this course examines the morphological, semantic and syntactic components of the grammar, as well as the interaction among them. The lectures are intended to provide students with a solid grounding in basic linguistic concepts, which will enable them to tackle linguistic problems, and formulate their own analyses to prepare them for further studies in the discipline. A wide range of data will be discussed to develop students’ sensitivity toward linguistic phenomena with systematic properties in form, meaning and structure.

The acquisition of first language by children has been considered a remarkable feat. How do children accomplish this feat so rapidly and effortlessly? What are the stages they go through in mastering the different aspects of language? What does the development of language in children tell us about the human language faculty? These questions will be examined in light of modern linguistic theory, and nativist and interactionist accounts will be compared. Topics in second language acquisition will also be covered. Questions such as how interlanguage grammars develop in adults and the role of the mother tongue in the construction of interlanguage grammar will be addressed.

Each student will be guided by a supervisor throughout the processes from literature review, setting up research questions, data collection, applying appropriate research methodology and writing up results.
